? re:cholesterol test results

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎01-09-2014 04:36 PM

I had a blood draw this morning and got the results this afternoon and now have a couple questions.

 

    Dec 2012                 Jan 2014

HDL  51                  HDL 43

LDL  44                  LDL  58

Trig   97                 Trig   64

 

Cholesterol HDL ratio was 2.2 now it's 2.7

 

The numbers all look good but I'm trying to find out why the good stuff went down and the bad stuff went up -- especially since my diet has improved the last 6 months.  Could it be because I'm eating fairly low carb so that I'm getting more protein?  Is there any way improve on these #'s while eating this way? 

What's the significance of the chol. hdl ratio? 

I'm assuming the trigs went down because I rarely eat any processed foods now.  

 

I won't know what my A1c is for a couple more weeks because that's done in the doctor's office.

 

Thanks for any help you can give me.  I don't post often but have gained a wealth of information from reading the boards everyday -- so thank you!!! 

 

Yoopermom

 

 

Diagnosed with type 2 diabetes in August of 2003
Metformin 1000 - 1500 mg 2003 - 2014
Currently diet and exercise controlled

‎01-09-2014 04:50 PM

Hopefully, the chart below will comfort you about your numbers:

 

http://www.vaughns-1-pagers.com/medicine/cholesterol-range.htm

 

Your doctor can be a bit more specific, but you numbers look pretty darn good to me.  The HDL is getting a bit on being borderline low.  The only way to increase it is exercise.  The fact that it has dropped would suggest that you have slacked off a bit in this area.  The reason for your drop in Triglycerides is most likely due to your reducing fat in your diet or increasing the amount of good fats versus bad fats, intentionally or not, which is a good thing.  As far as your heart is concerned, you're doing pretty darn good.


"No one can make you feel inferior without your consent." -- Eleanor Roosevelt


Toujeo 70 units in the morning and at bedtime
Novolog 50 units with each meal
Metformin 1000 mg twice daily
Glipizide ER 5 mg daily
Neurontin (gabapentin) 300 mg three times daily (neuropathy)
Metoprolol 50 mg twice daily (hypertension)
lisinopril 40 mg daily (hypertension)
Crestor 10mg at bedtime (hypercholesterolemia)
Arthrotec 50 three times daily (Rheumatoid Arthritis)
Multivitamin daily
Aspirin 81 mg daily
Lovaza 2 gm twice daily

‎01-09-2014 05:17 PM

Thanks for replying hornet. I'm not worried so much about the #s as much as the fact that they seem to be going backwards.

Funny you should mention exercise to help with the HDL -- I actually started exercising about 6 months ago doing at least 30 minutes/day 5-6 days/week. That's why I was surprised to see the HDL go down.

I'm trying to keep my heart in good shape because of a family history of heart disease -- don't want to go down that road!

Yoopermom
Diagnosed with type 2 diabetes in August of 2003
Metformin 1000 - 1500 mg 2003 - 2014
Currently diet and exercise controlled

‎01-09-2014 11:55 PM

Hve you noticed any other changes, such as weight loss or gain?  You can actually gain weight without it being a problem, if it is due to gain in muscle.  A pound of muscle will still be smaller in volume than a pound of fat.  A change in body fat can be a reason for some of the changes in numbers.


"No one can make you feel inferior without your consent." -- Eleanor Roosevelt

‎01-10-2014 02:03 AM

Yoopermom wrote:

I had a blood draw this morning and got the results this afternoon and now have a couple questions.

 

    Dec 2012                 Jan 2014

HDL  51                  HDL 43

LDL  44                  LDL  58

Trig   97                 Trig   64

 

Cholesterol HDL ratio was 2.2 now it's 2.7

 

The numbers all look good but I'm trying to find out why the good stuff went down and the bad stuff went up --

Triglycerides usually respond mostly to the amount of carbs you eat--eat less carbs, and the trigs go down. Your LDL is quite low, lower than the target range of <70 for someone with both diabetes and a history of heart disease. Are you taking a statin, or have they always been low?  The HDL is a bit lower than you want it--exercise can help, and eating good fats, such as avocados and nuts might help there, but the reality is that for most people HDL and LDL levels are pretty hereditary and do not respond much to dietary changes. (Although they do for some people.)

 

Mostly those are very good numbers, that  many here would be very pleased with, and the fluctuation is not unusual.  HOw does it compare with past fluctuations of your numbers?

Morris

Diagnosed Type 2, with an A1c of 11.4 in 2003; averaging a 5.0 A1c since then with diet, exercise and Glipizide XL + meds for blood pressure and cholesterol.  A bit dated, but scroll down on this page if you want to know more ...

Most of us would love to have your numbers....The LDL recommendation is for under 70 and only in rare cases does having low LDL cause problems....you might like to read this http://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/high-blood-cholesterol/expert-answers/cholesterol-leve....

Re: ? re:cholesterol test results

‎01-12-2014 01:31 PM

Exercise and nuts helped my HDLs

 

We're still working on the LDLs....for me, my LDLs are high because of the conversion of unused carbohydrates into fat by the insulin. 

 

Yours may have gone up due to diet or for the same reason as mine....though I eat as well as I can, my body's inability to process carbs gets worse and worse......so I'm on a statin to try to turn it around...it had gotten so bad that I had NAFLD...after a year on a low dose of pravastatin (a very mild statin), my liver has improved a lot, but still working on the LDLs.

 

Lower triglycerides are an indication that you are eating much lower carbs now.....excess carbs (and for us, a "normal" amount is "excess" when the body can't process them efficiently) will be converted to excess pyruvate which is converted to excess acetyl CoA which is converted to excess triglycerides. 

 

My triglycerides are always at the low end of normal so I know I'm doing the best I can with my diet for diabetes. 

 

I also take fish oil, 3-4 grams a day, I think that helps all of this as well. 

TikTok2

• Diabetes on both sides of my family.
• Assumed trouble metabolizing sugar as long as I can remember; migraines induced by hunger, very sleepy after meals high in carbohydrates from childhood. Learned how to avoid sugar and lots of complex carbs early on.
• Since early 2000s, "prediabetes" controlled through low carb diet and exercise, mostly walking. FBG 95-105, A1c below 6; glucose tolerance test was borderline.
• But weight drifted upwards but working on it.
• NAFLD brought under control with pravastatin.
• Metformin ER, 500 mg, started sept 2013 when A1c reached 6.5 despite diet and exercise regiment since early 2000s. A1c back down to ~6.0.
